content: The "Border Tax Equity Act of 2009" is the short title of this Act. It includes findings and declarations of policy. The "Border Tax Equity Act of 2009" outlines findings regarding the use of indirect taxes like value-added taxes (VAT) in 150 countries, with an average VAT rate of 15.7%. Direct taxes like corporate income taxes rebated upon export are considered export subsidies under WTO rules, while indirect taxes like VAT rebates are not seen as subsidies. The curr_chunk discusses the disparate treatment of border taxes affecting US agricultural producers, manufacturers, and service providers due to indirect taxes acting as export subsidies for foreign exporters and resulting in double taxation for US exporters. The curr_chunk highlights the significant impact of border tax inequity on US businesses, with foreign governments providing VAT rebates to their producers exporting to the US while collecting VAT equivalent taxes on US imported goods. This resulted in a combined goods and services disadvantage of $474 billion in 2007. Congress has long recognized the prejudicial effect of this disparate treatment of border taxes. The US has recognized the unfair treatment of border taxes and aims to negotiate a solution through various trade acts passed by Congress. The US aims to revise WTO rules regarding border taxes to address the disadvantage faced by countries relying on direct taxes. Congress emphasizes the need to resolve this issue in WTO negotiations. If WTO negotiations fail to revise rules on border taxes to address the disadvantage faced by countries relying on direct taxes, Congress may consider legislative action due to the significant trade distortions affecting US agricultural producers, manufacturers, and service providers. If the United States Trade Representative fails to certify to Congress by the specified date that trade negotiating objectives regarding border tax treatment have been met, certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code and Tariff Act will take effect after 90 and 120 days respectively. If the United States Trade Representative does not certify to Congress by January 1, 2010, that trade negotiating objectives on border tax treatment have been met, section 314 of the Tariff Act of 1930 will apply to exports of services from the United States. Appropriations will be made as necessary for payments related to these exports. Until the special account under section 4491 of the Internal Revenue Code is established and adequately funded, section 314 of the Tariff Act of 1930 will apply for payments related to exports of services from the United States.
